tutorial.title: Rick and Morty - Part 1
tutorial.descriptionContent: Ready to embark on an interdimensional journey? In this phase, we're diving into the multiverse of JSON. We'll parse and present data from the world of Rick and Morty, setting the foundation for our character compass.

executableContent.instructions:
Welcome to the **Rick and Morty** project. We'll build a webpage that displays characters from the Rick and Morty show using an API.

1. Set up the basic HTML file.
    - `<!doctype html>`, `html`, `head`, `title`, `body`, and `link` tags.
    - A `title` tag with `"Rick and Morty Character Compass"` as its content, or choose a text you like more.
    - A `link` tag inside the `head` tag, with reference to a stylesheet file named `"style.css"`.
    - An `h1` header with `"Rick and Morty Character Compass"` as its content, or choose a text you like more.
    - A `div` tag with an id attribute of `"characters-container"`.
    - Add a `script` tag below the `body` closing tag with an `src` attribute pointing to `"script.js"`.

files.name: index.html
files.solvedContent: Rick and Morty Character Compass

executableContent.instructions:
We will start with creating one character object to work with.

1. Create a variable named `data`, and assign it an object literal with a `characters` property. The `characters` property will be an array. Inside the array, place a single object to represent a character.
2. Add the properties `name`, `status`, `species`, and `image` to the object. Fill them with data about Rick.

```JSON
{
  "name": "Rick Sanchez",
  "status": "Alive",
  "species": "Human",
  "image": "https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character/avatar/1.jpeg"
}
```

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

hints.title: How should my code look?

executableContent.instructions:
Next, let's add a couple more characters to our characters array.

1. Add objects for Morty and Summer Smith with the same properties as Rick.
   ```JSON
   {
     "name": "Morty Smith",
     "status": "Alive",
     "species": "Human",
     "image": "https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character/avatar/2.jpeg"
   },
   {
     "name": "Summer Smith",
     "status": "Alive",
     "species": "Human",
     "image": "https://rickandmortyapi.com/api/character/avatar/3.jpeg"
   }
   ```

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Now, it's time to use JavaScript to create HTML elements from our JavaScript data.

1. Firstly, get a reference to the `characters-container` element in the HTML and store it in a variable named `charactersContainer`.
2. Next, use JavaScript's built-in `forEach()` method on `data.characters`, passing in a callback function that takes a single parameter, which will represent the current item in the array (`character`).
3. Inside the callback function, create new `div` elements with class `card` and append them to the `charactersContainer`.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
The final step is to fill each card with the character's information. 1. Inside the callback function to the `forEach` method, use a template literal to generate the HTML of a card using the character's properties: `image`, `name`, `status` and `species`. Assign this HTML as the `innerHTML` of the `card` div. Use the following code or something similar, but make sure to set the class `character-image` for the image, `character-detail`, and `attribute` for the `p` and `span` tags, respectively. ```JavaScript card.innerHTML = `

Name: ${character.name}

Status: ${character.status}

Species: ${character.species}

`; ```

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Now that the HTML and JavaScript are completed, it's time to style the page.

1. Create a new CSS file and style the `body` tag. Set:
    - `font-family` to `Arial, sans-serif`
    - `background-color` to `#f4f4f4`
    - `padding` to `20px`
    - `text-align` to `center`

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
As a next step, we'll style the container that holds all the characters' cards.

1. Select it by its id `characters-container`. Add the following CSS:
    - `display: flex`
    - `justify-content: space-around`
    - `flex-wrap: wrap`

With these properties, the cards will display in a row, evenly distributed, and they will wrap onto new lines if there isn't enough space.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
The images need some love.

1. Select them by their class name, `character-image`.
    - Set both the `width` and `height` to `100px`.
    - Make the images round by setting a `border-radius` of `50%`.
    - Add some margin to the bottom for spacing, using `margin-bottom`.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: script.js
style.css

executableContent.instructions:
The individual cards could use some love.

1. Select them by their class name `.card`. Ensure to do the following:
    - Display the card items in a column and center the items. Achieve this by creating a rule for `.card` and using `flexbox`, `flex-direction`, `align-items`, and `justify-content`.
    - Add some `padding` and `margin` for spacing.
    - Round the edges by setting a `border-radius`.
    - Set the background color to `white` and the `width` of cards to a value you like.
    - Add a box shadow for depth.

files.name: index.html
files.content: Rick and Morty Character Compass
files.solvedContent: Rick and Morty Character Compass

files.name: script.js
style.css

executableContent.instructions:
More styling!

1. Set the `font-weight` of all elements with class `attribute` to `bold` and add some spacing on the right by setting a value for `margin-right`.
2. Finally, add some `margin` to all elements with the class `character-detail` for better spacing.
